emotional_anchors.magicFix: Our senior lead would be emended on a 12 month contract on a high day rate, unlocking budget to invest in new hires. An assistant, new business sales and marketing functions and processes in place.
emotional_anchors.hardTruth: We are stuck at half a mill recurring revenue with the current people and process.
emotional_anchors.sacrifice: A stable high income and security.
emotional_anchors.exitMindset: I think about it but haven't planned
emotional_anchors.tuesdayTest:
It’s a Tuesday morning in London. I wake up at 7am, as I do every weekday, and help get the kids ready for school. There’s no rush or anxiety — mornings feel structured and calm. After the school run, I head to our studio space in London: our own creative area within a shared working environment. It feels established, familiar, and purposeful.

I’m at my desk by mid-morning, drink in hand, reviewing our financial targets, forecasts, and pipeline for Q1 and the year ahead with the senior management team. The numbers are clear and predictable. We’re discussing priorities, not firefighting. Decisions are based on data, not gut feel or urgency.

My role is focused on direction, leadership, and quality — guiding the business, supporting senior clients, and making strategic calls. I’m no longer involved in day-to-day marketing activity or outbound sales outreach. Those systems run well without me, owned by the right people.

The business feels steady, profitable, and well-run.
emotional_anchors.emergencyLog:
A client requested a detailed financial overview and forecast for 2026 with very little notice. I had to drop other priority work to pull this together.

I was the only person able to do it accurately because I currently manage invoicing, POs, and final scope approvals, and the financial information lives across those touchpoints. While nothing was technically “broken,” the dependency on me meant an unplanned request immediately became urgent and disruptive.

It highlighted a single-point-of-failure risk and a lack of delegated financial visibility elsewhere in the business.
emotional_anchors.finalInsight: Starting my own businesses was a role of the dice at a difficult time (start of covid and having our second child). It has caused great stress over the years and I will do everything in my power to make it work... I have given myself 10 years to achieve what i feel to be a successful, scalable and profitable businesses that outweighs the advantages of working for someone else to earn higher returns.
emotional_anchors.sacrificeList: A stable high income and security.
emotional_anchors.fiveYearVision:
It’s a Tuesday morning in London. I wake up at 7am, as I do every weekday, and help get the kids ready for school. There’s no rush or anxiety — mornings feel structured and calm. After the school run, I head to our studio space in London: our own creative area within a shared working environment. It feels established, familiar, and purposeful.

I’m at my desk by mid-morning, drink in hand, reviewing our financial targets, forecasts, and pipeline for Q1 and the year ahead with the senior management team. The numbers are clear and predictable. We’re discussing priorities, not firefighting. Decisions are based on data, not gut feel or urgency.

My role is focused on direction, leadership, and quality — guiding the business, supporting senior clients, and making strategic calls. I’m no longer involved in day-to-day marketing activity or outbound sales outreach. Those systems run well without me, owned by the right people.

The business feels steady, profitable, and well-run.
emotional_anchors.hiddenFromTeam: How tight cash flow can get during some periods, that we are not as profitable as we need to be.
emotional_anchors.suspectedTruth: We spend more money in parts of the business than I like to admit.
emotional_anchors.changeReadiness: Ready - as long as I understand the why
emotional_anchors.coreFrustration:
The bottleneck created by a lack of dedicated new-business support and activation, which is slowing growth more than it should.

We have strong delivery, client trust, and a clear proposition, but without consistent, senior-led new-business capability in place, growth relies too heavily on ad hoc effort and founder time rather than a repeatable system.
emotional_anchors.unlimitedChange:
I would elevate our market position significantly and put a fully in-house, senior-led sales and marketing function in place.

That means clear positioning, consistent messaging, and experienced leadership owning the entire funnel end to end — brand, marketing, partnerships, and sales — rather than it being founder-led or fragmented across roles.

Done properly, this would remove a major dependency on me, smooth revenue, increase deal quality, and allow the business to scale more predictably without compromising standards or culture.
emotional_anchors.successDefinition: Creating a business that runs profitably without me
emotional_anchors.relationshipMirror: A complex beast that gives as much as it takes.
emotional_anchors.avoidedConversation: The hard conversation linked to the reality that if we dont get our most senior person in the team embedded into at least a 6 month full time contract to cover his cost to the business, that we will have to let him go as part of a restructure.
emotional_anchors.operationalFrustration: Making the business hit a higher profitability.

page5_nextSteps.theAsk: You've given yourself 10 years to make this work. You said you'll "do everything in your power" to build something that outweighs the alternative. firstStep.headline: You'll Know What It's Actually Worth

gaps.emotionalImpact: You've already sacrificed 'holidays and time spent with family' - how much more before the plan becomes real?

gaps.pattern: You said 'nothing with respect to the numbers of my business' when asked what you suspect - which means either everything's fine, or you haven't looked closely enough to know.

gaps.emotionalImpact: You want to 'pass on my wealth to my family' but can't plan what you can't measure

gaps.title: You're Still The Only One
gaps.pattern: Your magic fix? 'Having a highly reliable person/company that I could delegate responsibility for dealing with issues to.' Your core frustration? 'Not having someone to delegate to.' You're a one-man band who wants an orchestra.
gaps.timeImpact: Every issue lands on you - even when 'fortunately nothing in the last month'
gaps.shiftRequired: Build the delegation structure that lets you step back without stepping out

page3_journey.headerLine: From Here to Home Office Freedom

page4_numbers.headerLine: The Investment in Your Property Portfolio Future
page4_numbers.realReturn: The business value is unknown precisely - that's exactly why we start with benchmarking. There may be hidden assets sitting outside the earnings valuation - excess cash, property, equipment - that a buyer pays for separately. But the real return? It's being 'at home in my home office' sorting paperwork for your investment properties, with 'a highly reliable person/company' handling the issues. It's holidays that actually happen. It's time with family that doesn't get sacrificed.
page4_numbers.personalCost: You've sacrificed 'holidays and time spent with family.' That's not a number on a spreadsheet - that's birthdays, anniversaries, lazy Sundays that turned into work days. And you're worried that stepping back means 'not having enough to do for my mental health.' The cost of staying isn't just financial. It's the gap between the life you're living and the Tuesday you described.

page5_nextSteps.theAsk: You've built something that works. You describe it as 'very rewarding' despite the ups and downs. But you've also admitted you're avoiding thinking about 'giving it up' because you're worried about what comes next. Here's the thing - planning the exit doesn't mean leaving tomorrow. It means leaving on your terms, when you're ready, with your family taken care of. That starts with a conversation.

thisWeek.tone: This isn't a sales pitch. We'll dig into what 'enough' actually looks like for you - what the property portfolio needs to generate, what you want to pass on to family, and whether the business can get you there. You'll leave with clarity, whether we work together or not.
thisWeek.action: 30-minute call to talk through your exit timeline and inheritance planning questions

firstStep.headline: You'll Know What You're Working With
firstStep.recommendation: Start with benchmarking. You can't plan an exit without knowing your starting point. You can't structure inheritance without knowing what you're passing on. Everything else - finding someone to delegate to, building the transition plan - flows from knowing the number.
firstStep.theirWordsEcho: You want to plan 'how to pass on my wealth to my family.' That starts with knowing exactly what that wealth is worth today.

page5_nextSteps.urgencyAnchor: You've never taken a proper break. Not once. You've given up holidays and time with family to build this. At some point, the business needs to start giving back. Let's figure out when that point is - and make sure you're ready for it.
page5_nextSteps.closingMessage: You've built something that works. You describe it as 'very rewarding' despite the ups and downs. But you've also admitted you're avoiding thinking about 'giving it up' because you're worried about what comes next. Here's the thing - planning the exit doesn't mean leaving tomorrow. It means leaving on your terms, when you're ready, with your family taken care of. That starts with a conversation.

page1_destination.visionVerbatim: At home in your home office. Sorting out paperwork and admin for your various investment properties. Popping out to visit properties, checking on required works. Not firefighting. Not being the only person who can fix things. Just... managing your wealth, on your terms.

gaps.title: Money Walking Out The Door
gaps.pattern: "Payroll is too high as a percentage of sales. This is currently manageable, but leaves the company vulnerable in a downturn."
gaps.timeImpact: Staff issues pulling you in even on holiday
gaps.shiftRequired: Get the payroll right before any buyer looks under the hood
gaps.emotionalImpact: You know it needs fixing. You've known for a while. The stress of it follows you on holiday.
gaps.financialImpact: £193k/year excess - staff costs at 36.5% vs the 28% benchmark

gaps.title: The Conversation You've Been Avoiding
gaps.pattern: "Redundancies." - that's the avoided conversation. "The company would benefit from strong leadership; we are overstaffed and we need to reduce the payroll in order to better compensate the staff we need to retain."
gaps.timeImpact: This drags on every month you don't act
gaps.shiftRequired: Have the hard conversation once, properly, so you can move forward
gaps.emotionalImpact: "I get stressed and bothered with this and very annoyingly, it tends to happen when I'm on holiday."
gaps.financialImpact: Roughly 2 excess employees based on productivity - revenue per head at £108k vs £120k benchmark

gaps.title: No Baseline For What It's Worth
gaps.pattern: "I'm completely on top of my financials" - but do you know what a buyer would actually pay? What's dragging the multiple down? What's hidden value you're not seeing?
gaps.timeImpact: Every month without knowing is a month you can't plan properly
gaps.shiftRequired: Get a proper valuation baseline before anything else
gaps.emotionalImpact: You can't plan the exit you want without knowing the starting point
gaps.financialImpact: Indicative range is £1.1M - £1.9M - that's a £800k gap you need to understand

gaps.pattern: "Some people may have an inkling, but it would be my plan to find an exit strategy."

gaps.shiftRequired: Get the plan out of your head and onto paper with someone holding you accountable
gaps.emotionalImpact: You've built something that runs without you - but you've never actually tested that by taking a proper break
gaps.financialImpact: Cost of inaction: £387k+ over 2 years just from the payroll excess

page5_nextSteps.theAsk: You've built something that runs without you, James. Under 30 hours a week. Strategic work, not firefighting. That's rare. But you've never actually taken a proper break to test it. And you're still carrying the redundancy conversation you haven't had, the payroll you know is too high, and an exit plan that only exists in your head. Let's get it out of your head and onto paper.

gaps.emotionalImpact: That nagging feeling that you're working hard but can't measure if it's actually working
gaps.financialImpact: Unknown - to be confirmed from accounts

gaps.title: The MVP Is Holding Everything Hostage
gaps.pattern: "Getting our MVP finished and out in the wild" - this is what's frustrating you day-to-day. Until it's done, nothing else moves.
gaps.timeImpact: Your time is consumed by something that should already be behind you
gaps.shiftRequired: Get the MVP out the door so you can shift from building to growing
gaps.emotionalImpact: The vision of those investment CEO calls feels further away while you're still in the weeds
gaps.financialImpact: Unknown precisely - but delayed launch means delayed revenue

gaps.title: The Exit Plan Lives In Your Head
gaps.pattern: You described a future where you're reviewing investments and playing Padel - but there's no documented roadmap from here to there.
gaps.timeImpact: Without a plan, every week is reactive rather than building towards something specific
gaps.shiftRequired: Turn the vision into a timeline with milestones you can actually track
gaps.emotionalImpact: That Tuesday morning vision stays a dream rather than becoming a deadline
gaps.financialImpact: Unknown - but unplanned exits typically leave 20-40% of value on the table

gaps.title: You're Carrying The Fear Alone
gaps.pattern: "It might fail." - that's the hard truth you've been avoiding. And you haven't told us what you hide from your team, which suggests you're carrying more than you're sharing.
gaps.timeImpact: Mental energy spent managing fear rather than building momentum
gaps.shiftRequired: Someone in your corner who can hold that fear with you and turn it into a plan
gaps.emotionalImpact: The weight of 'what if this doesn't work' sits on your shoulders alone
gaps.financialImpact: Unknown - but fear-based decisions rarely optimise for value

phases.headline: You'll Know Where You Stand
phases.feelsLike: Like finally stepping on the scales after avoiding them for months. The number might surprise you - but at least you'll know. No more guessing whether you're building something valuable or just staying busy.

phases.title: You'll Have Someone In Your Corner
phases.outcome: A documented exit plan with milestones, and someone holding you accountable to hitting them
phases.headline: You'll Have Someone In Your Corner
phases.feelsLike: Like having a co-pilot who's done this before. You said you're "completely ready - I'll do whatever it takes." This is where that commitment gets channelled into a plan that actually moves you towards those investment CEO calls and Padel evenings.
whatChanges: The exit roadmap moves from your head onto paper
Someone to share the 'it might fail' fear with - and turn it into contingency plans
Regular check-ins that keep you accountable to the Tuesday vision

page4_numbers.headerLine: The Investment in Your Tuesday Morning Vision
page4_numbers.realReturn: The business value is unknown until we do the benchmarking work. That's the point - you're building something you want to eventually step back from, but you don't know what it's worth yet. But the real return? Waking up at 5am for coffee and reading. Running before the boys wake up. Lunch with your wife. Padel with your mates. That's what you're buying.
page4_numbers.personalCost: We don't know yet what you've sacrificed to get here. We don't know your wife's name or how old the boys are. But we know you want to take them to school, have lunch with her, and pick them up for family dinner. That's the cost of staying stuck - those moments you're missing while you're 'getting the MVP finished.'

page5_nextSteps.theAsk: You said you're "completely ready - I'll do whatever it takes." That's rare. Most people say they want change but aren't willing to do the work. You've admitted the hard truth - "it might fail." That honesty is the foundation everything else gets built on. Let's turn that readiness into a plan.

thisWeek.tone: This isn't a sales pitch. We've got your Tuesday vision - the 5am coffee, the school runs, the Padel. But we're missing the details that make this real: what you've sacrificed, what the numbers actually look like, what's really keeping you up at night beyond 'it might fail.' Let's have that conversation.
thisWeek.action: 30-minute call to fill in the gaps we're missing

firstStep.headline: You'll Know What You're Building Towards
firstStep.recommendation: Start with the benchmarking. You can't scale towards something you haven't measured. Get the baseline valuation, identify what's dragging value down, and then every decision from here has a number attached to it.
firstStep.theirWordsEcho: "We would scale faster" - but you can't scale what you can't measure.

page5_nextSteps.urgencyAnchor: The boys won't be this age forever. Every school run you miss while stuck on MVP frustrations is one you don't get back. The Padel mates will find someone else to play with. The Tuesday you described is waiting - but it won't wait forever.
page5_nextSteps.closingMessage: You said you're "completely ready - I'll do whatever it takes." That's rare. Most people say they want change but aren't willing to do the work. You've admitted the hard truth - "it might fail." That honesty is the foundation everything else gets built on. Let's turn that readiness into a plan.

page1_destination.visionVerbatim: You wake up at 5am, grab a coffee and read for 30 minutes. Then head out for a run. Come home and take the boys to school. The rest of the day is spent on calls with your investment CEOs, walking the dogs and having lunch with your wife. You pick up the boys, take them home, have dinner as a family, then head out to play Padel with your mates in the evening.
page1_destination.clarityExplanation: You've painted a vivid picture of the life you want - the 5am coffee, the school runs, the Padel with mates. The direction is there. What's still emerging is the bridge between where you are now and becoming the investor reviewing your portfolio over lunch.
whatTheyWontBeDoing: Chasing the MVP to completion
Being the bottleneck for scaling
Worrying about whether it might fail
